instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the diagnostic of Raman spectroscopy (RS) in discriminating between normal-appearing and fresh neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection?
Output: Raman spectra were used in the diagnostic of Raman spectroscopy (RS) in discriminating between normal-appearing and fresh neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the diagnostic of Raman spectroscopy (RS) in discriminating between normal-appearing and fresh neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection?
Output: Tissue processing methods such as de-waxing, washing, and clearing with solvents were used in the diagnostic of Raman spectroscopy (RS) to discriminate between normal-appearing and fresh neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy in the diagnostic of Raman spectroscopy (RS) in discriminating between normal-appearing and fresh neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection and precision of the classification?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy and precision of the classification was percentage (%).

instruction: What machine learning methods were used to classify the spectra in this study?
Output: Gradient Boosting (GB) and Random Forest (RF) machine learning methods were used to classify the spectra in this study.

instruction: Can Raman spectroscopy (RS) be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for discriminating between normal-appearing and neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection?
Output: Raman spectroscopy (RS) has shown potential as a method for discriminating between normal-appearing and neoplastic tissue in patients undergoing glioma resection. Past study analyzing 63 fresh tissue biopsies, RS with machine learning algorithms achieved an accuracy and precision of 83% and 82%, respectively, in distinguishing between normal-appearing and neoplastic tissue. Additionally, 19 novel Raman shifts with known biological relevance were identified, further supporting the development of RS as an intraoperative tool for glioma detection. Therefore, RS can be considered as a promising method for discriminating between normal-appearing and neoplastic tissue in glioma resection, potentially offering advantages over traditional methods.
